subject: RE: [junit] how to test abstract class
msgSnippet: In your test class create an internal class that extends Parent, override Do1() and Do2() with empty methods that do nothing, then test Dosomething1() and
messageBody:
In your test class create an internal class that extends Parent,
override Do1() and Do2() with empty methods that do nothing, then test
Dosomething1() and Dosomething2() on that class you created. Shouldn't be
too bad.

-----Original Message-----
From: javalist [mailto:myjavalist@...]
Sent: Thursday, October 23, 2003 7:58 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] how to test abstract class



Hi:
there is a question confuse me. I have a abstract class and it has some
method which not abstract method.Now ,whether i must test it?
how to test ? help me.
Ex:
public abstract class Parent
{
public void Dosomething1()
{
..........
}
public void Dosmoething2()
{
...........
}
abstract public void Do1();
abstract public void Do2();
}
public class Child1 extends Parent
{
.....
}
public class Child2 extends Parent
{
....
}
May I test Dosomething1 for Child1 and Child2 separate ?
best regards.
